structures.name: triple_bullet_syndrome
structures.description: Topic sentence followed by exactly 3 bullets. Every time.
structures.pattern: paragraph followed by exactly 3 bullet points
structures.alternative: Vary list length. Use 2, 4, or 5. Or skip bullets entirely.

structures.name: not_x_but_y
structures.description: The 'Not X. But Y.' dramatic contrast.
structures.alternative: Just state the actual point. Drop the fake drama.

structures.name: rhetorical_then_answer
structures.alternative: State the point directly. If you need a question, let it breathe.

structures.name: colon_list_opener
structures.alternative: Vary openers. Start with the content, not a preamble.

structures.name: em_dash_addiction
structures.description: Overuse of em dashes for parenthetical asides.
structures.pattern: More than 2 em dashes per paragraph
structures.alternative: Use periods. Use commas. Em dashes are seasoning, not the main dish.

structures.name: mirror_intro_conclusion
structures.description: Conclusion that restates the intro almost verbatim.
structures.alternative: End with a new insight or a forward-looking statement. Don't loop back.

structures.name: fragment_for_emphasis
structures.description: One-word or two-word sentence fragment for dramatic effect.
structures.alternative: Use sparingly. Once per piece max. Not every paragraph.

structures.name: identical_paragraph_lengths
structures.description: Every paragraph is 3-4 sentences. Uniform blocks.
structures.pattern: All paragraphs within 1 sentence of same length
structures.alternative: Mix it up. One sentence. Then five. Then two. Rhythm matters.

structures.name: listicle_brain
structures.description: Everything becomes a numbered or bulleted list.
structures.pattern: More than 50% of content is in list format
structures.alternative: Write prose. Lists are for reference docs, not blog posts.

structures.name: hedge_stack
structures.pattern: Multiple hedging words in same sentence
structures.alternative: Pick one hedge or commit to the statement.
